articles.title: NOVEMBER IN THE YEAR 1977
articles.summary: This document outlines a schedule of astronomical events and meetings for October, November, and December 1977, organized by groups such as the Peninsula Astronomical Society and the Far-out Club. Events include various star parties (indoor, public, and club-specific), general meetings, and board meetings, along with planning for a graze occultation expedition. It also features a report on a past field observation event at Lexington School, which was partially successful despite significant light pollution.

articles.title: BLURBS
articles.summary: The article promotes a weekly telescope makers class at Chabot Observatory, emphasizing its educational value in optics, social atmosphere, and role in planning future events for astronomy enthusiasts. It also informs club members about a reduced December event schedule due to holidays, briefly mentions a past talk on the AANC Conference, and an ongoing request for a new title for Ed Schell's reports.

articles.title: NEWS NOTEZ Ed.Schell
articles.summary: Recent astronomical observations have identified LMC X-1 as a supernova remnant and revealed the ultraviolet spectrum of quasar 3C 273, potentially indicating a closed universe. In planetary science, the Viking Landers have detected and photographed frost on Mars. Additionally, a positive leap second is scheduled for December 31, 1977.

articles.title: EDITORIAL
articles.summary: This editorial argues that individuals who do not volunteer at the public star party for West Valley classes at Sanborn Canyon should not complain if West Valley attendees participate in other star parties. The author emphasizes the importance of community support and shared responsibility in hosting public astronomy events.

articles.title: GREAT RED SPOT ON MERIDIAN LCT
articles.summary: This article presents a detailed schedule for observing Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) as it transits the meridian from late October to early December. An accompanying observing report notes the GRS is currently faint, occasionally pink, and primarily identifiable by its effect on surrounding belts, though timing predictions by Jim Van Nuland remain highly accurate.

articles.title: An Announcement
articles.summary: The document announces an upcoming graze occultation event on November 4th-5th, encouraging participation and treating it like a star party. It also features a report on a successful Fremont Peak Star Party held in October, attended by hundreds from various astronomy clubs and colleges. Additionally, the document includes classified ads for used telescopes and an extensive list of double stars with observational data.

articles.title: COMET UPDATE
articles.summary: This "COMET UPDATE" provides current observational data and future predictions for various comets. It highlights brightest reported visual magnitudes for Comet Kohler (7.5) and Comet Encke (8.8), along with details about Kohler's tail and predicted positions through December. The article also lists 19 comets under observation since August 1st, noting periodic ones, and reports the discovery of a new comet, Sanguin (1977n).
